trans-unit.source: LOB application test environment | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: LOB application test environment | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a web-based, line of business application in a hybrid cloud environment for IT pro or development testing.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a web-based, line of business application in a hybrid cloud environment for IT pro or development testing.

trans-unit.source: This topic steps you through creating a hybrid cloud environment for testing an intranet line-of-business (LOB) application hosted in Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: This topic steps you through creating a hybrid cloud environment for testing an intranet line-of-business (LOB) application hosted in Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: Here is the resulting configuration.
trans-unit.target: Here is the resulting configuration.

trans-unit.source: For an example of a production LOB application hosted in Azure, see the Line of business applications architecture blueprint at Microsoft Software Architecture Diagrams and Blueprints.
trans-unit.target: For an example of a production LOB application hosted in Azure, see the Line of business applications architecture blueprint at Microsoft Software Architecture Diagrams and Blueprints.

trans-unit.source: This configuration simulates an LOB application in Azure production environment from your location on the Internet.
trans-unit.target: This configuration simulates an LOB application in Azure production environment from your location on the Internet.

trans-unit.source: It consists of:
trans-unit.target: It consists of:

trans-unit.source: A simplified on-premises network (the Corpnet subnet).
trans-unit.target: A simplified on-premises network (the Corpnet subnet).

trans-unit.source: A cross-premises virtual network hosted in Azure (TestVNET).
trans-unit.target: A cross-premises virtual network hosted in Azure (TestVNET).

trans-unit.source: A site-to-site VPN connection.
trans-unit.target: A site-to-site VPN connection.

trans-unit.source: A line of business server, SQL server, and secondary domain controller in the TestVNET virtual network.
trans-unit.target: A line of business server, SQL server, and secondary domain controller in the TestVNET virtual network.

trans-unit.source: This configuration provides a basis and common starting point from which you can:
trans-unit.target: This configuration provides a basis and common starting point from which you can:

trans-unit.source: Develop and test LOB applications hosted on Internet Information Services (IIS) with a SQL Server 2014 database backend in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Develop and test LOB applications hosted on Internet Information Services (IIS) with a SQL Server 2014 database backend in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Perform testing of this hybrid cloud-based IT workload.
trans-unit.target: Perform testing of this hybrid cloud-based IT workload.

trans-unit.source: There are three major phases to setting up this hybrid cloud test environment:
trans-unit.target: There are three major phases to setting up this hybrid cloud test environment:

trans-unit.source: Set up the hybrid cloud environment for testing.
trans-unit.target: Set up the hybrid cloud environment for testing.

trans-unit.source: Configure the SQL server computer (SQL1).
trans-unit.target: Configure the SQL server computer (SQL1).

trans-unit.source: Configure the LOB server (LOB1).
trans-unit.target: Configure the LOB server (LOB1).

trans-unit.source: If you do not already have an Azure subscription, you can sign up for a free trial at <linkText>Try Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you do not already have an Azure subscription, you can sign up for a free trial at <linkText>Try Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you have an MSDN Subscription, see <linkText>Azure benefit for MSDN subscribers</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you have an MSDN Subscription, see <linkText>Azure benefit for MSDN subscribers</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Use the instructions in the <linkText>Set up a hybrid cloud environment for testing</linkText><title></title> topic.
trans-unit.target: Use the instructions in the <linkText>Set up a hybrid cloud environment for testing</linkText><title></title> topic.

trans-unit.source: Because this test environment does not require the presence of the APP1 server on the Corpnet subnet, feel free to shut it down for now.
trans-unit.target: Because this test environment does not require the presence of the APP1 server on the Corpnet subnet, feel free to shut it down for now.

trans-unit.source: This is your current configuration.
trans-unit.target: This is your current configuration.

trans-unit.source: For Phase 1, you can also set up the simulated hybrid cloud test environment.
trans-unit.target: For Phase 1, you can also set up the simulated hybrid cloud test environment.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Set up a simulated hybrid cloud environment for testing</linkText><title></title> for the instructions.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Set up a simulated hybrid cloud environment for testing</linkText><title></title> for the instructions.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Management Portal, start the DC2 computer if needed.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Management Portal, start the DC2 computer if needed.

trans-unit.source: Next, create an Azure Virtual Machine for SQL1 with these commands at an Azure PowerShell command prompt on your local computer. Prior to running these commands, fill in the variable values and remove the < and > characters.
trans-unit.target: Next, create an Azure Virtual Machine for SQL1 with these commands at an Azure PowerShell command prompt on your local computer. Prior to running these commands, fill in the variable values and remove the < and > characters.

trans-unit.source: Next, connect to the new SQL1 virtual machine using the local administrator account.
trans-unit.target: Next, connect to the new SQL1 virtual machine using the local administrator account.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane of the Azure Management Portal, click Virtual Machines, and then click Running in the Status column for SQL1.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane of the Azure Management Portal, click Virtual Machines, and then click Running in the Status column for SQL1.

trans-unit.source: In the task bar, click Connect.
trans-unit.target: In the task bar, click Connect.

trans-unit.source: When prompted to open SQL1.rdp, click Open.
trans-unit.target: When prompted to open SQL1.rdp, click Open.

trans-unit.source: When prompted with a Remote Desktop Connection message box, click Connect.
trans-unit.target: When prompted with a Remote Desktop Connection message box, click Connect.

trans-unit.source: When prompted for credentials, use these:
trans-unit.target: When prompted for credentials, use these:

trans-unit.source: Name: SQL1\\[Local administrator account name]
trans-unit.target: Name: SQL1\\[Local administrator account name]

trans-unit.source: Password: [Local administrator account password]
trans-unit.target: Password: [Local administrator account password]

trans-unit.source: When prompted with a Remote Desktop Connection message box referring to certificates, click Yes.
trans-unit.target: When prompted with a Remote Desktop Connection message box referring to certificates, click Yes.

trans-unit.source: Next, configure Windows Firewall rules to allow traffic for basic connectivity testing and SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: Next, configure Windows Firewall rules to allow traffic for basic connectivity testing and SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: From an administrator-level Windows PowerShell command prompt on SQL1, run these commands.
trans-unit.target: From an administrator-level Windows PowerShell command prompt on SQL1, run these commands.

trans-unit.source: The ping command should result in four successful replies from IP address 10.0.0.1.
trans-unit.target: The ping command should result in four successful replies from IP address 10.0.0.1.

trans-unit.source: Next, add the extra data disk as a new volume with the drive letter F:.
trans-unit.target: Next, add the extra data disk as a new volume with the drive letter F:.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane of Server Manager, click File and Storage Services, and then click Disks.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane of Server Manager, click File and Storage Services, and then click Disks.

trans-unit.source: In the contents pane, in the Disks group, click disk 2 (with the Partition set to Unknown).
trans-unit.target: In the contents pane, in the Disks group, click disk 2 (with the Partition set to Unknown).

trans-unit.source: Click Tasks, and then click New Volume.
trans-unit.target: Click Tasks, and then click New Volume.

trans-unit.source: On the Before you begin page of the New Volume Wizard, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Before you begin page of the New Volume Wizard, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select the server and disk page, click Disk 2, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select the server and disk page, click Disk 2, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, click OK.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, click OK.

trans-unit.source: On the Specify the size of the volume page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Specify the size of the volume page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Assign to a drive letter or folder page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Assign to a drive letter or folder page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select file system settings page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select file system settings page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Confirm selections page, click Create.
trans-unit.target: On the Confirm selections page, click Create.

trans-unit.source: When complete, click Close.
trans-unit.target: When complete, click Close.

trans-unit.source: Run these commands at the Windows PowerShell command prompt on SQL1:
trans-unit.target: Run these commands at the Windows PowerShell command prompt on SQL1:

trans-unit.source: Next, configure SQL Server 2014 to use the F: drive for new databases and for user account permissions.
trans-unit.target: Next, configure SQL Server 2014 to use the F: drive for new databases and for user account permissions.

trans-unit.source: From the Start screen, type SQL Server Management, and then click SQL Server 2014 Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: From the Start screen, type SQL Server Management, and then click SQL Server 2014 Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: In Connect to Server, click Connect.
trans-unit.target: In Connect to Server, click Connect.

trans-unit.source: In the Object Explorer tree pane, right-click SQL1, and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In the Object Explorer tree pane, right-click SQL1, and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the Server Properties window, click Database Settings.
trans-unit.target: In the Server Properties window, click Database Settings.

trans-unit.source: Locate the Database default locations and set these values:
trans-unit.target: Locate the Database default locations and set these values:

trans-unit.source: For Data, type the path f:\Data.
trans-unit.target: For Data, type the path f:\Data.

trans-unit.source: For Log, type the path f:\Log.
trans-unit.target: For Log, type the path f:\Log.

trans-unit.source: For Backup, type the path f:\Backup.
trans-unit.target: For Backup, type the path f:\Backup.

trans-unit.source: Note: Only new databases use these locations.
trans-unit.target: Note: Only new databases use these locations.

trans-unit.source: Click the OK to close the window.
trans-unit.target: Click the OK to close the window.

trans-unit.source: In the Object Explorer tree pane, open Security.
trans-unit.target: In the Object Explorer tree pane, open Security.

trans-unit.source: Right-click Logins and then click New Login.
trans-unit.target: Right-click Logins and then click New Login.

trans-unit.source: In Login name, type CORP\User1.
trans-unit.target: In Login name, type CORP\User1.

trans-unit.source: On the Server Roles page, click sysadmin, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: On the Server Roles page, click sysadmin, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Close Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: Close Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: This is your current configuration.
trans-unit.target: This is your current configuration.

trans-unit.source: First, create an Azure Virtual Machine for LOB1 with these commands at the Azure PowerShell command prompt on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: First, create an Azure Virtual Machine for LOB1 with these commands at the Azure PowerShell command prompt on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: Next, connect to the LOB1 virtual machine with the CORP\User1 account credentials.
trans-unit.target: Next, connect to the LOB1 virtual machine with the CORP\User1 account credentials.

trans-unit.source: Next, configure a Windows Firewall rule to allow traffic for basic connectivity testing.
trans-unit.target: Next, configure a Windows Firewall rule to allow traffic for basic connectivity testing.

trans-unit.source: From an administrator-level Windows PowerShell command prompt on LOB1, run these commands.
trans-unit.target: From an administrator-level Windows PowerShell command prompt on LOB1, run these commands.

trans-unit.source: The ping command should result in four successful replies from IP address 10.0.0.1.
trans-unit.target: The ping command should result in four successful replies from IP address 10.0.0.1.

trans-unit.source: Next, configure LOB1 for IIS and test access from CLIENT1.
trans-unit.target: Next, configure LOB1 for IIS and test access from CLIENT1.

trans-unit.source: Run Server Manager, and then click Add roles and features.
trans-unit.target: Run Server Manager, and then click Add roles and features.

trans-unit.source: On the Before you begin page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Before you begin page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select installation type page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select installation type page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select destination server page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select destination server page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Server roles page, click Web Server (IIS) in the list of Roles.
trans-unit.target: On the Server roles page, click Web Server (IIS) in the list of Roles.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, click Add Features, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, click Add Features, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select features page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select features page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Web Server (IIS) page, click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Web Server (IIS) page, click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Select role services page, select or clear the check boxes for the services you need for testing your LOB application, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Select role services page, select or clear the check boxes for the services you need for testing your LOB application, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Confirm installation selections page, click Install.
trans-unit.target: On the Confirm installation selections page, click Install.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the installation of components has completed and then click Close.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the installation of components has completed and then click Close.

trans-unit.source: Log on to the CLIENT1 computer with the CORP\User1 account credentials, and then start Internet Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the CLIENT1 computer with the CORP\User1 account credentials, and then start Internet Explorer.

trans-unit.source: In the Address bar, type http://lob1/ and then press ENTER.
trans-unit.target: In the Address bar, type http://lob1/ and then press ENTER.

trans-unit.source: You should see the default IIS 8 web page.
trans-unit.target: You should see the default IIS 8 web page.

trans-unit.source: This is your current configuration.
trans-unit.target: This is your current configuration.

trans-unit.source: This environment is now ready for you to deploy your web-based application on LOB1 and test functionality and performance from the Corpnet subnet.
trans-unit.target: This environment is now ready for you to deploy your web-based application on LOB1 and test functionality and performance from the Corpnet subnet.
